title: HS-393
text:
The Hughes 393 (sometimes referred to as the HS-393) is a <a href="communications%20satellite">communications satellite</a> <a href="satellite%20bus">bus</a> introduced in 1985 by <a href="Hughes%20Space%20and%20Communications%20Company">Hughes Space and Communications Company</a>. It was a <a href="Spin-stabilized%20satellite">spin-stabilized</a> bus that had twice as much power as the <a href="HS-376">HS-376</a> platform.
Design.
The satellite bus was designed and manufactured by <a href="Hughes%20Space%20and%20Communications%20Company">Hughes</a>. It had a launch mass of , a mass of after reaching <a href="geostationary%20orbit">geostationary orbit</a>, and an 8-year design life. When stowed for launch, its dimensions were in height and in diameter. With its solar panels fully extended its height was .
Its power system generated approximately 2,350 <a href="Watt">watts</a> of power at <a href="BOL%20%28engineering%29">beginning of life</a> and 2,200 at end of life, thanks to two cylindrical solar panels. These panels used K7 and K4-3/4 solar cells, with more than twice the number of cells than on the <a href="HS-376">HS-376</a>. The bottom panel was retracted around the body and top panel for launch, and extended downwards for operation. It also had two 38 <a href="ampere%20hour">Ah</a> <a href="Nickel%E2%80%93hydrogen%20battery">NiH2 batteries</a>.
Its propulsion system was composed of two <a href="R-4D">R-4D</a> <a href="Liquid%20Apogee%20Engine">liquid apogee engines</a> with a thrust of . It also had two axial and four radial <a href="Bipropellant%20rocket">bipropellant</a> <a href="Thrusters%20%28spacecraft%29">thrusters</a> for <a href="Orbital%20station-keeping">station-keeping</a> and <a href="attitude%20dynamics%20and%20control">attitude control</a>. It included enough propellant for <a href="Geostationary%20transfer%20orbit">orbit circularization</a> and 8 years of operation.
Its payload was composed of a antenna that fed <a href="Ku%20band">Ku band</a> <a href="Transponder%20%28satellite%20communications%29">transponders</a>.
Satellites.
The HS-393 was a more powerful platform than the <a href="HS-376">HS-376</a>, being able to supply 2,200 kW of power versus the 1,400 kW of the HS-376HP. Only three were ever built.
